block.p: HOCKEY Goulet Nets 500th Goal Michel Goulet scored his 500th goal, the 17th National Hockey League player to reach the mark, and helped the host Chicago Blackhawks tie the Calgary Flames, 5-5, last night. Goulet scored on a breakaway with 37 seconds left in the first period, beating goaltender Jeff Reese. Goulet has 500 goals in 951 career N.H.L. games. He also scored 28 goals with Birmingham of the World Hockey Association in 1978-79, although those do not count in his overall total. Goulet scored 456 goals in 813 games with Quebec.(AP)

HOCKEY Goulet Nets 500th Goal Michel Goulet scored his 500th goal, the 17th National Hockey League player to reach the mark, and helped the host Chicago Blackhawks tie the Calgary Flames, 5-5, last night. Goulet scored on a breakaway with 37 seconds left in the first period, beating goaltender Jeff Reese. Goulet has 500 goals in 951 career N.H.L. games. He also scored 28 goals with Birmingham of the World Hockey Association in 1978-79, although those do not count in his overall total. Goulet scored 456 goals in 813 games with Quebec.(AP)

TENNIS Becker Outlasts Courier Boris Becker rallied from a two-set deficit and outlasted Jim Courier in five grueling sets in a battle of the world's top-ranked player and the former No. 1 in the Donnay indoor championship yesterday in Brussels. In a 4-hour-54-minute struggle, Becker, now ranked fifth in the world, beat Courier, 6-7 (5-7), 2-6, 7-6 (12-10), 7-6 (7-5), 7-5. Despite the defeat, Courier remains ranked No. 1.(AP) A First for Washington: MaliVai Washington captured his first professional singles title with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Wayne Ferreira in the Federal Express International in Memphis. Washington, seeded No. 14, was too strong from the baseline for the seventh-seeded South African.(AP) SWIMMING Australian Sets Mark Keiren Perkins of Australia broke his world record in the 800-meter freestyle last night at the New South Wales state championships in Sydney, Australia. Perkins, 18, clipped 1.25 seconds off the old mark with a time of 7 minutes 46.60 seconds.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Duke Wins No. 20 Duke ended a five-year losing streak at North Carolina State as Grant Hill continued to star in place of Bobby Hurley, leading the top-ranked Blue Devils (20-1 over all, 10-1 in the Atlantic Coast Conference) to a 71-63 victory yesterday in Raleigh, N.C. Hill scored 20 points and played 40 minutes for the third game in a row since being moved to point guard after Hurley broke his foot. The Wolfpack (9-15, 3-8) lost their ninth in a row.(AP) GOLF Parry Passes Norman Craig Parry shot a five-under-par 68 to overtake the six-time champion, Greg Norman, and win the Australian Masters golf championship yesterday in Sydney. Parry finished with a nine-under-par total of 283, three shots ahead of Norman, who carded a final-round 76 and remained without a victory since June 1990.(AP) A Milestone for Janzen: Lee Janzen earned the first victory of his three-season career as he defeated Bill Britton by one stroke in the Northern Telecom Open in Tucson, Ariz. Janzen, 27, won with an 18-under-par 270 total after shooting a 65 yesterday. The victory was worth $198,000. (AP) Colbert Wins in Playoff: Jim Colbert sank a 3-foot birdie putt on the fourth playoff hole to defeat George Archer and win the $450,000 Suncoast Classic in Tampa, Fla. Colbert shot a seven-under-par 64. He and Archer both shot 13-under-par 200's for 54 holes, shattering the tournament record by seven shots.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Victory, but No Record After a mad dash from Madrid to Los Angeles, Andre Cason almost came up with another world-record dash. Cason, who set a world indoor mark in the 60 meters Friday night in Spain, missed a world record in the 50 meters by one-hundredth of a second in Saturday night's Sunkist Invitational. Cason was clocked in 5.62 seconds in the 50 yesterday. The world record of 5.61 was set by Manfred Kokot of East Germany in 1980 and tied by James Sanford in 1981.(AP) Brooklyn Girl Extends Streak: Fifteen-year-old Jowanna McMullen of Brooklyn extended an unbeaten streak to three years in the Colgate women's games yesterday at Madison Square Garden by winning the high school 1,500-meters final in 4 minutes 44.46 seconds. McMullen also took home the Cosby Award, named after Bill Cosby and presented to the most outstanding performer in the Colgate preliminaries. Two Colgate marks fell yesterday. Alicia Moss of Brooklyn set an overall record in the 1,500-meter run in the 30's-plus category with a time of 4:22:14, and Neffertitti Cooper of Philadelphia set a record in the 200 meters in the Elementary B category with a time of 26.69 seconds. YACHTING New Zealand Triumphs Challengers for the America's Cup resumed their second round of trial racing yesterday in San Diego after a postponement Saturday because of high winds. New Zealand defeated the Spirit of Australia team by 12 minutes 12 seconds in a race that began with a minor collision during pre-start maneuvers. Umpires imposed a penalty against Spirit for the infraction. In other matches, Japan beat France by 1:42; Italy beat Sweden by 13:32; and Spain beat Challenge Australia by 5:46. Among the defense teams, William Koch's America3 defeated Dennis Conner's yacht, Stars & Stripes, by 4:33.
